title: 104_s858
content: The United Nations Participation Act of 1945 is amended to include new restrictions on intelligence sharing with the United Nations. The United Nations Participation Act of 1945 is amended to include restrictions on sharing US intelligence with the United Nations. The President must certify that specific security requirements are in place for the provision of intelligence information to the UN. The United Nations Participation Act of 1945 is amended to include restrictions on sharing US intelligence with the United Nations. The President must certify security requirements for providing intelligence information to the UN, including background investigation procedures, protection of information, notification of unauthorized disclosures, and prohibitions on access by ineligible countries. The United Nations Participation Act of 1945 is amended to include restrictions on sharing US intelligence with the United Nations. Prohibitions on access to intelligence information by countries designated as state supporters of terrorism or not eligible for direct provision through bilateral agreements are outlined. Measures to protect intelligence sources and methods from unauthorized disclosure are also specified. The President can waive these provisions with written certification to Congress. The President can waive restrictions on sharing US intelligence with the United Nations by providing written certification to Congress. Periodic reports on the types and volume of intelligence provided to the UN must be submitted to specific committees in Congress. The President must report to Congress on the intelligence provided to the United Nations and any unauthorized disclosures. The President cannot delegate these duties. The President cannot delegate duties under this section, which does not affect the Director of Central Intelligence's authority to protect intelligence sources and methods or the provisions of the National Security Act of 1947.
